Posts.Content: On 10/15/2009 LuckyJean wrote:   On 9/5/2009 JanieK wrote: I too, like so many of you, after taking Aromasin for 2 years, find that the side effects are intolerable and have stopped taking it.  The depressed mood, the restlessness and feelings of rage were getting to be too much for me and it was beginning to effect my relationship with family members.  I knew it was happening, but had little success with trying to control it on my own.  I thought that it was just from the trauma of the whole cancer experience and perhaps long term effects of chemotherapy.  I was Dx'd with Stage III, estrogen positive breast cancer and did the usual chemo, radiation, bi-lateral mastectomy.  For reconstruction I chose a TRAM flap on the tumor side and implantation on the non-cancer side.  This decision has worked very well for me and I'm extremenely pleased.  It's just the dang Aromasin.  I can't stand the pain anymore...I  am 61 and feel 101 !  The depression became unbearable and about 2 weeks ago I decided to chuck the pills.  The depression cleared up within 2 days and it's so awesome to feel more like myself again.  The joint pain, that has just about crippled my hands has not improved at all, but the foot and ankle pain has mostly vanished !  I'm really afraid to tell my oncologist that I've taken myself off of Aromasin, because he's pretty much in denial of my symptoms and wants to blame it on age.  I'm very athletic and one of my passions is hiking, and I mean, hard hikes.  I'm no whimp and can't believe that this joint pain and constant sweating is caused by aging alone.  My husband and I have been searching everywhere to uncover reliable evidence, based on research, what the chances are of the CA recurring if I don't finish out the 5 years (3 more to go) of Aromasin therapy.  Is there anyone out there that can point us to reliable, research based information ?        JanieK  I do not have an answer as I am searching myself for reliable information. I just wanted to say Thank you for your letter that makes me feel as if I have NOT lost my mind and that the pain and swelling that I am experiencing is not in my head and is not just due to my age (65). I also have been a very active person and had some arthritis in my knees but could always exercise and walk forever.  Now however I feel so crippled (even tho I force myself to keep moving) and I too feel like an old woman. I took Tomaxafen for 2 years and had a small amount of pain but I have been on Aromasin for 6 months and I am ready to stop the medication. I will keep checking to see if we find out any new information. Thank you again ! Jeannie It's nice to hear from you !  Thank you for your response.  Lately I've been going against the "rules" and have been icing my hands.  The tendons, specially the one that starts at the wrist and goes up the thumb, has been so knotted up that the inside half of my hands feel like thick, non-pliable rubber, and I have to ice in the morning and take a pain pill just to get my hands moving.  I then ice 2 more times per day and this is the only thing that has given any type of relief.  I'm afraid to NOT take Aromasin, but I find I'm taking it on again, off again because I just can't live with the side effects.  I too, feel like a crippled up old lady and sometimes I let myself cry a few tears, just for some release of frustration. It's hard for others to understand that even doing normal routine things that we used to take for granted can cause so much pain, swelling and discouragement, but I try to live my life as close to normal as possible and can't wait until 3 more years have gone by and I can quit the Aromasin.  Hope you can find some reliable ways to ease this discomfort and enjoy moving your body again without pain.

Posts.Content: I too, like so many of you, after taking Aromasin for 2 years, find that the side effects are intolerable and have stopped taking it.  The depressed mood, the restlessness and feelings of rage were getting to be too much for me and it was beginning to effect my relationship with family members.  I knew it was happening, but had little success with trying to control it on my own.  I thought that it was just from the trauma of the whole cancer experience and perhaps long term effects of chemotherapy.  I was Dx'd with Stage III, estrogen positive breast cancer and did the usual chemo, radiation, bi-lateral mastectomy.  For reconstruction I chose a TRAM flap on the tumor side and implantation on the non-cancer side.  This decision has worked very well for me and I'm extremenely pleased.  It's just the dang Aromasin.  I can't stand the pain anymore...I  am 61 and feel 101 !  The depression became unbearable and about 2 weeks ago I decided to chuck the pills.  The depression cleared up within 2 days and it's so awesome to feel more like myself again.  The joint pain, that has just about crippled my hands has not improved at all, but the foot and ankle pain has mostly vanished !  I'm really afraid to tell my oncologist that I've taken myself off of Aromasin, because he's pretty much in denial of my symptoms and wants to blame it on age.  I'm very athletic and one of my passions is hiking, and I mean, hard hikes.  I'm no whimp and can't believe that this joint pain and constant sweating is caused by aging alone.  My husband and I have been searching everywhere to uncover reliable evidence, based on research, what the chances are of the CA recurring if I don't finish out the 5 years (3 more to go) of Aromasin therapy.  Is there anyone out there that can point us to reliable, research based information ?

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for the prayers !  I also have the tingling, burning in my hands, specially my fingers and my feet are kinna numb, but this has been Dx'd as peripheral neuropathy.  I'm on pain meds for that and it's tolerable now.  I've tried the glucosamine and have tried a product called Neuropathy RX and it was like a miracle, but alas, it made me very nauseated.  I really don't like to complain about all of this, but my oncologist is still in denial that these could all be side effects of chemo or Aromasin.  He wanted to blame it on my age, but I never felt like this before I had cancer treatments and I'm relieved to find out that I'm not the only one.  If it weren't for the internet, I wouldn't have known where to go to see if what I'm experiencing is common.  I can tolerate the pain and neuropathy, but it's the depression and fatigue.  I know it's not really how I feel and I just have to keep telling myself it's only temporary.  May the Lord bless you and keep you and may He make His face to shine upon you !!  We'll keep fighting the good fight, won't we ?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the reply !   I try going back on Aromasin, but after 1 day back on it, the depression starts to set in again. I hate having that lump in my throat all the time, wondering why I'm so depressed.  When I'm off the Aromasin that depressed feeling vanishes !  I'm sure I don't want to go into Stage IV cancer, but it's so difficult to think of spending the next 3 years with that horrible dark cloud hanging over my head all of the time.  Being post-menopausal I'm not sure if Tamoxafin is the drug for me, but I'll call my oncologist and talk this over with him.
